Colin, this issue is outside my expertise but I agree that (I think) 
patte=
rns in the sequences shouldn't really matter for the purposes of 
NEAT.  Th=
ere is no a priori reason to believe that the pattern is any 
more or less =
beneficial than something without a pattern.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.=
com, "Colin Green" <locster01@...> wrote:
>
> Thanks for this. It's interes=
ting to that George Marsaglia's KISS 
RNG
> is given the thumbs up, I used =
his XOR shift algorithm as the basis
> for my FastRandom class in SharpNeat=
. I may well switch over to 
using
> the KISS algorithm though based on the=
 discussion in this article. 
Oh
> and also someone made a comment on the c=
odeproject page where
> FastRandom lives - "Worst ever random generator!...=
Passes FIPS 140-1
> with approximately 0.7 %. "
> 
> Not sure why this guy =
was so passionate about RNG's but I do intend 
to
> check out this FIPS tes=
t one day.
> 
> Overall though I don't think NEAT is going to be particular=
ly harmed
> by the kind of flaws inherent in some of these RNGs. For most o=
f 
what
> we do we just want uniformly distributed numbers to mix things up=
 a
> bit. Any patterns in the generated sequence probably aren't
> particul=
arly detrimental IMHO. Interested to know if others agree or
> not.
> 
> Co=
lin
